title: In Vitro Phagocytosis of Myelin Debris by Bone Marrow-Derived Macrophages
procedures:
The methods described here and in Section 2 have been approved by the Florida State University Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) and follows the guidelines set forth in the Guide for Care and Use of Laboratory Animals, 8th edition. All animals used in this in this protocol are house in a dedicated laboratory animal facility until use. No in vivo experimentation was performed prior to sacrifice. Animal numbers were based on experimental need using average cell and myelin collections as a guide in order to minimize usage.
NOTE: This protocol describes the generation of bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs) (Section 1), the preparation of fluorescently labeled brain-derived myelin debris (Section 2), the general procedure for analyzing myelin debris phagocytosis (Section 3), and the general procedure for analysis of myelin debris lipid accumulation (Section 4). Reagent preparation, cell harvesting and manipulation, myelin collection and labeling, and assay performance should be completed in a laminar airflow biosafety cabinet.
1. Generation of Primary Bone Marrow-Derived Macrophages
Preparation of complete macrophage culture medium (CMCM)
	NOTE: Macrophage generation from bone marrow requires the use of macrophage colony-stimulating factor (M-CSF). This preparation utilizes L929 murine fibroblast conditioned media as the source of M-CSF.
	
Generate L929 murine fibroblast conditioned media by culturing cells in 145 mm dishes with 50 mL of high glucose (4500 mg/L L-glucose) Dulbecco's Modified Eagle Medium (DMEM) supplemented with 5% new born calf serum (NCS) and Penicillin/Streptomycin for 7 days.
Collect media from cultures into 50 mL conical centrifuge tubes and centrifuge for 30 minutes at 3500 x g, 4 °C.
Filter supernatants through a 0.2 µm syringe filter into a new 50 mL conical centrifuge tube. Conditioned media can be stored at -80 °C for up to 6 months.

To high glucose DMEM, add 5% vol/vol NCS, 15% vol/vol L929 murine fibroblast conditioned DMEM, and 1% Penicillin/Streptomycin. Media can be stored at 4 °C for 2-3 months. Warm to 37 °C before use.
Collection of primary bone marrow cells and macrophage induction
NOTE: Using this protocol one mouse will generate approximately 20 million bone marrow-derived macrophages (BMDMs).
	
Euthanize the desired number of 8-10 week old mice using standard CO2 asphyxiation guidelines followed by cervical dislocation.
Sanitize the animal using 70% (vol/vol) ethanol:H2O, saturating the fur.
Cut a small opening in the abdomen and carefully pull back the skin to reveal the underlying tissue. Take care to not puncture the peritoneal cavity.
Remove both hind legs starting at the hip and ending at the ankle. Place the collected tissue into a 100 mm Petri dish containing 5-10 mL sterile phosphate buffered saline (PBS) supplemented with 1% Penicillin/Streptomycin.
NOTE: When processing several animals make sure to keep dishes on ice to limit tissue degradation.
Remove muscle and connective tissue from the bone using a scalpel. Only the femur and tibia are used for cell collection, the fibula can be discarded.
Expose the marrow cavity of the collected bones by trimming a small section from each end with a scalpel.
Using a 25g needle, flush the marrow cavities with CMCM into a 50 mL conical centrifuge tube. The bones will appear white once they have been sufficiently flushed.
Once collection is completed, agitate aspirates with an 18g needle for 30-90 s to generated a single cell suspension.

NOTE: An optional red blood cell (RBC) lysis step may be performed at this point. It has recently been suggested that intracellular iron content may influence the effects of myelin debris upon macrophage polarization16. For information regarding the inclusion of a RBC lysis step refer to Trouplin et al.17.
Filter the suspension through a 70 µm sterile cell strainer into a new 50 mL conical centrifuge tube.
Seed collected cells evenly into 145 mm cell culture dishes containing 15-20 mL CMCM. Use approximately three culture dishes per mouse sacrificed. Incubate cultures at 37 °C, 5% CO2.
After 72 hours wash plates once with sterile PBS to remove non-adherent cells, then add 15-20mL fresh CMCM. Incubate cultures for an additional 4 days at 37 °C, 5% CO2. After 7 days of total culture, the hematopoietic bone marrow cells initially isolated will be mature BMDMs (Figure 1).
2. Generation of Fluorescently Labeled Brain-Derived Myelin Debris
NOTE: All reagents can be stored at 4 °C for up to 1 month.
Preparation of myelin debris collection reagents 
Prepare Tris·Cl buffer solution.
		
To 800mL distilled deionized H2O (ddiH2O) add 20 mL of 1 M Tris·Cl, pH 7.45 (20 mM final concentration) and 20 mL of 100 mM Na2EDTA (2 mM final concentration).
Adjust pH to 7.45. Adjust volume to 1000 mL with ddiH2O. Filter solution through a 0.2 µm filtration unit.
Prepare 1 M sucrose solution.
		
To 100 mL of Tris·Cl buffer solution, add 68.46 g of sucrose. Adjust volume to 200 mL with Tris·Cl buffer solution. Filter solution through a 0.2 µm filtration unit.
Prepare 200 mL of 0.32 M sucrose solution by diluting the 1 M solution with the Tris·Cl buffer solution 0.83:0.16 (vol/vol).

Prepare 150 mL of 0.83 M sucrose solution by diluting the 1 M solution with the Tris·Cl buffer solution 0.83:0.16 (vol/vol).
Collection of brain-derived crude myelin debris
NOTE: The collection method described here is for the isolation of crude myelin debris.
	
Euthanize 10-12 mice 8-10 weeks of age using standard CO2 asphyxiation guidelines followed by cervical dislocation.
Dissect the brains and place them in a 100 mm dish containing 10 mL of 0.32 M sucrose solution. Keep the dish on ice.
Using sterile surgical scissors cut the brains into pieces approximately 5 mm3 in size.
Transfer the tissue to a 50 mL conical centrifuge tube and add approximately 30 mL of 0.32 M sucrose solution.
Homogenize with a sterile hand-held rotary homogenizer, until a smooth solution is achieved.
Dilute the homogenized brains to a final volume of 90 mL with 0.32 M sucrose solution.
To six 38.5-mL thin-walled polypropylene ultracentrifuge tubes, add 20 mL of 0.83 M sucrose solution.
Gently add the homogenized brain solution to the top of the 0.83 M sucrose solution, taking care not to mix the two layers.
Balance each tube with the 0.32 M sucrose solution.
Centrifuge at 100,000 x g for 45 min at 4°C using an appropriate pre-cooled ultracentrifuge rotor. Set rotor acceleration and deceleration to their minimum values to reduce myelin debris loss.
Collect the myelin debris from the interface of the two sucrose densities.
NOTE: Debris should appear as a white band towards the center of the tube.
Combine the crude myelin debris into a 50 mL conical centrifuge tube and adjust the volume to approximately 35 mL using Tris·Cl buffer solution.
Homogenize the crude myelin debris with a sterile hand-held rotary homogenizer for 30-60 s.

Evenly divide the suspension between 6 clean ultracentrifuge tubes and balance with an appropriate volume of Tris·Cl buffer solution.
Centrifuge at 100,000 x g for 45 min at 4°C using an appropriate pre-cooled ultracentrifuge rotor. Set rotor acceleration and deceleration to their maximum values.
As solid white pellets will now be visible, discard the supernatant and re-suspend the pellets in 10-15 mL of Tris·Cl buffer solution.
Evenly divide the suspension between 2 clean ultracentrifuge tubes and balance with an appropriate volume of Tris·Cl buffer solution.
Centrifuge again at 100,000 x g for 45 min at 4 °C using an appropriate pre-cooled ultracentrifuge rotor. Set rotor acceleration and deceleration to their maximum values.
Discard the supernatant and resuspend the pellets in 5-6 mL of sterile PBS and divide the suspension between an appropriate number of pre-weighed 1.5 mL micro-centrifuge tubes.
Centrifuge at 22,000 x g for 10 min at 4 °C.
Discard the supernatant and determine the weight of the myelin debris pellets.
Re-suspend the pellets in PBS to a final concentration of 100 mg/mL.
NOTE: Ten to twelve brains is enough to produce 10-15 mL of 100 mg/mL myelin debris. Myelin debris can be store at -80 °C for 6 months.
Myelin debris fluorescent labeling
Prepare the 50 µM carboxyfluorescein succinimidyl ester (CFSE) solution immediately before use.
		
Using sterile PBS, dilute a 5 mM stock solution of CFSE prepared with 100% dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) to a final working concentration of 50 µM.
Filter solution through a 0.2 µm syringe filter.
Thaw the desired amount of 100 mg/mL myelin debris and re-suspend with a sterile 29g needle.
NOTE: Freezing the myelin debris will cause it to drop out of solution requiring resuspension before use.
Transfer myelin debris to a pre-weighed 1.5 mL micro-centrifuge tube.

Centrifuge at 14,800 x g for 10 min at 4°C. Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the myelin debris in 200 µL of CFSE solution per 100 µL myelin debris pelleted.
Incubate for 30 min at room temperature (RT) protected from light.
Centrifuge at 14,800 x g for 10 min at 4 °C. Discard the supernatant.
Resuspend the pellet in 600-800 µL of wash buffer (0.2 µm filter sterilized 100 mM glycine in PBS).
Centrifuge at 14,800 x g for 10 min at 4 °C. Discard the supernatant.
Repeat steps 2.3.8-2.3.9 twice more.
After the final wash, determine the weight of the myelin debris pellet and re-suspend to 100 mg/mL with sterile PBS.
		Note: Labeled myelin debris can be store at -80 °C for up to 6 months.
3. Myelin Debris Phagocytosis Assay
NOTE: The following is the basic method for observing phagocytosis of fluorescently labeled myelin debris. Addition of other treatments and experimental conditions will need to be optimized by the investigator.
Preparation of treatment plates
For each 145 mm plate, collect mature BMDMs into a 15 mL conical centrifuge tube using 5-6 mL of 10 mM ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) in Dulbecco's phosphate-buffered saline (dPBS) (pH 7.4).
NOTE: Do not use trypsin as it may alter the activation state of the cells18.
Add an equal volume of pre-warmed CMCM to each tube of collected cells.
Centrifuge at 180 x g for 8 min at 20 °C. Discard the supernatant.
Re-suspend cells in CMCM and count.
To each well of a 24-well cell culture plate, add 1x105 cells in 1 mL of CMCM.
Incubate at 37 °C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Myelin debris treatment and analysis
Add 10 µL of 100 mg/mL CFSE labeled myelin debris to each well (1 mg/mL final concentration).

Incubate for 1-3 hours at 37 °C, 5% CO2.
Wash plate 3 times with sterile PBS to remove non-engulfed myelin debris.
Add 400 µL of 4% paraformaldehyde to each well. Incubate for 30 min at RT.
Wash plate 2 times with sterile PBS.
Add 400 µL of Hoechst 33258 solution to each well. Incubate for 5 min at RT protected from light.
Wash plates 2 times with sterile PBS.
Add 200 µL of Fluoro-gel with Tris buffer to each well to reduce photobleaching.
Image cells using an inverted epi-fluorescent capable microscope.
NOTE: The excitation and emission wavelengths of CFSE are 494 nm and 521 nm, respectively.
Divide the number of CFSE positive cells by the number of nuclei to determine relative myelin debris uptake.
Prior to imaging, maintain plates for up to 7 days at 4 °C protected from light.
4. Quantification of Intracellular Lipids Via Oil Red-O Staining
NOTE: The following is the basic method for observing intracellular myelin-debris-derived lipids. The use of CFSE labeled myelin debris is not recommended for fluorescent quantification of ORO staining due to spectral overlap. Addition of other treatments and experimental conditions will need to be optimized by the investigator.
Preparation of staining solutions
Prepare 0.5% Oil Red-O (ORO) staining solution.
		
Slowly add 100 mL of 100% propylene glycol (1,2-Propanediol) to 0.5 g of ORO (1-([4-(Xylylazo)xylyl]azo)-2-naphthol) while stirring.
Heat solution at 95 °C for 15 min or until all large particles are dissolved.
NOTE: Do not heat over 100 °C.
Filter solution through a piece of filter paper while still warm into a new container.
Allow solution to cool overnight at RT. Solution can be stored for up to 1 year at RT.
Prepare 85% propylene glycol solution.

Add 85 mL of 100% propylene glycol to 15 mL of ddiH2O. Stir until mixed. Solution can be stored for up to 1 year at RT.
Preparation of treatment plates
Prepare a 24-well plate following the method outlined in Section 3.
Incubate at 37 °C, 5% CO2 for 24 h.
Myelin debris treatment 
Add 10 µL of 100 mg/mL myelin debris to each well (1 mg/mL final concentration).
Incubate for 1-3 h at 37 °C, 5% CO2.
Wash plate 3 times with sterile PBS to remove non-digested myelin debris.
		Note: At this point, plates can either undergo immediate fixation or fresh CMCM can be added, and cells returned to incubation for additional time points.
Add 400 µL of 4% paraformaldehyde to each well. Incubate for 30 min at RT.
Wash plate 2 times with sterile PBS then procced to staining.
ORO staining and analysis
Wash fixed plate 3 times with ddiH2O.
Add 400 µL of 100% propylene glycol to each well and incubate for 5 min at RT.
NOTE: This will reduce carryover of ddiH2O.
Aspirate the propylene glycol and add 400 µL of ORO solution to each well.
Incubate for 8 min at 60 °C.
Aspirate the ORO solution. Then, add 400 µL of 85% propylene glycol to each well and incubate for 5 minumintes at RT.
Wash plate 3 times with ddiH2O.
Add 400 µL of Hoechst 33258 solution to each well. Incubate for 5 min at RT, protected from light.
Wash plates 2 times with sterile PBS.
Add 200 µL of Fluoro-gel with Tris buffer to each well.
Image cells using an inverted epi-fluorescent capable microscope. ORO can be imaged using a standard Texas Red or DsRed filter set.

Quantify relative lipid retention by determining the ORO positive area in each image field and dividing it by the number of nuclei.
Maintain plates for 7 days at 4 °C protected from light.
